Expectation1: Be friendly and polite in daily interactions
Situation1: Having just moved in, they prepare a small cake to share with nearby neighbors when they happen to meet.
Expectation2: Take scheduled breaks and adhere to work hours
Situation2: Management closely monitors break logs because the phone queue remains consistently full.
Story: I had just moved into my new apartment, and the scent of the cake I’d baked for my neighbors filled the kitchen. I wanted to make a good impression, to be the kind of neighbor who’s friendly and approachable. As I wrapped the cake, I glanced at the clock—my telemarketing shift was about to start. Management had been strict lately, watching our break times like hawks because the call queue never seemed to shrink. I knew if I took even a few extra minutes, it would be flagged. Just as I was about to log in, I heard footsteps in the hallway. My neighbor, Mrs. Kim, was coming home. This was the perfect chance to introduce myself and share the cake, just as I’d hoped. But my break wasn’t scheduled for another two hours. If I stepped out now, I’d risk a warning at work. If I waited, I might miss the chance to connect with Mrs. Kim, and I didn’t want to seem unfriendly on my first day. My heart pounded as I stood frozen, cake in hand, torn between being a good neighbor and a responsible employee.
